data.text: Contents
Authorising usage of FP10 prescriptions in clinical areas ........................................... 13
Introduction

An FP10 is a green paper prescription that can be dispensed by any community pharmacy. FP10 prescriptions are controlled stationary that require secure storage, an immediate full audit trail of issue and comprehensive stock management. They are routinely used by GP's, and are sometimes issued by the Trust.
FP10s provide the patient with a choice as to which community pharmacy to have their prescription dispensed.

When a hospital-issued FP10 is dispensed by a community pharmacy the cost of the prescription is charged back to the prescribing hospital. The use of FP10 prescriptions may result in an increase to the in-tariff drug cost for that Trust. This is because the hospital Trust may be able to secure more favourable contract prices for medications. However, when FP10 prescriptions are in use, it allows the site hospital pharmacy departments to provide more resource from staff establishment to clinical ward based services.
The Trust pharmacy department can run nationally collated reports of all items prescribed on an FP10 prescription.

FP10 prescriptions should not be dispensed by the hospital site Pharmacy. Only in extenuating circumstances, with agreement from a Senior Manager within Pharmacy, can they be processed by a hospital pharmacy department within the Trust.
Usual NHS prescription charges and exemptions apply to FP10 prescriptions.  Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Provide guidance as to when FP10NC and FP10SS prescriptions forms can and should be used;
Ensure staff awareness of the importance/value of security related to all FP10 prescriptions;
Detail the processes that should be followed when FP10 usage is appropriate;
Provide clear guidance to those in Pharmacy on the re-ordering and supply of FP10 prescription forms.
Definitions

table_items.text: A log book of all FP10 issues from a clinical area

A Drug which is currently not on the Trust formulary. This means the drug has not been requested via the Trust formulary application process AND has been approved by the Medicines Assurance Committee (MAC) or Mid and South Essex Health and Care Partnership Medicines Optimisation Committee (HCPMOC). Approval via MAC or HCPMOC is dependent on status of the drug.
The Electronic Prescribing & Medicines Administration (ePMA) and Pharmacy stock control system approved for use in the Trust.
Medicines where the cost is solely attributable to the Trust and cannot be reimbursed by other NHS agencies (e.g. NHS England, CCG etc.)

In the context of FP10 prescriptions, where a mistake has been made that cannot be legally corrected on the prescription and therefore is rendered unusable. Examples include printing the wrong way, incorrect patient details, wrong drug etc.
In the context of FP10 prescriptions, where an FP10 prescription is written but then decided is not required and should not be issued to the patient.
Any clinic room, ward area or office space used to conduct either face to face or virtual outpatient appointments/patient assessment where a prescription could be issued

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Committee responsibilities
4.1.1 MSE Medicines Assurance Group (MAG)
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Groups (MOSG);
Where necessary, escalating concerns to the Chief Nurse or Site Director of Nursing or Medical Director as appropriate;
Exception reporting to the MSE or Site Risk and Compliance Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning the use of FP10 prescriptions.
4.1.2 Site Medicines Optimisation & Safety Group (MOSG), or equivalent
Monitoring this policy through incident reports;
Receiving and actioning site-specific exception reports on FP10 usage;
Escalating issues to site corporate governance groups as appropriate.
4.1.3 Pharmacy Directorate Governance Group
Ensuring this policy is adhered to by the pharmacy department;
Reviewing FP10 usage across all sites in accordance with this policy and associated departmental procedures;
Escalating issues to corporate governance groups as appropriate.
4.1.4 Site/Trust Division/Directorate Governance Groups
Ensuring attendance and engagement at the site Medication Optimisation and Safety Group;
Engaging with the nominated Directorate/Division Pharmacist and taking action in response to FP10 monitoring reports and escalation of issues from pharmacy concerning their use.
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive)
4.2.1 Chief Pharmacist
Setting the overall framework and policy standards for FP10 usage across the organisation, in line with regulatory and best practice guidance;
Ensuring a monitoring process exists and functions for policy standards.
4.2.2 Chief Nursing Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the Site Pharmacy, Head of Department & Pharmacy Operations Manager that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated FP10 issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
4.2.3 Site Director of Nursing
Ensuring that there is policy compliance on site by all professions they oversee and that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated FP10 issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
4.2.4 Associate Directors of Nursing / Midwifery and Matrons
Ensuring accountable Individuals (see below) are implementing and monitoring FP10 management in their areas;
Ensuring areas under their responsibility are appropriately monitored and supported following audit to ensure sustained improvement is achieved;
Reporting FP10 usage errors and near miss incidents using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.
4.2.5 Chief Medical Officer
Ensuring that there is policy compliance and liaising with the Site Medical Directors that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated FP10 issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
4.2.6 Site Medical Director
Ensuring that there is policy compliance on site by all professions they oversee and that the service is operating effectively;
Ensuring any escalated FP10 issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
4.2.7 Site Pharmacy Head of Department
Overall oversight of the delivery of FP10 framework on behalf of the Chief Pharmacist for their site;
Authorising requests for FP10 use in clinical area;
Sign off and challenge on completed investigations pertaining to FP10 use.
4.2.8 Site Pharmacy Operations Manager
Overseeing the day to day delivery of the FP10 policy framework for their sites;
Ensuring the site pharmacy department/s are managing FP10 prescriptions securely and appropriately in line with this policy and departmental SOPs, including maintaining documentation;
Supporting review of, and ensuring departmental SOPs are within date and fit for purpose;
Reviewing requests for FP10 use in a clinical area, and liaising with the Site Pharmacy Head of Department in a timely way;
Ensuring relevant committees and directorate/divisional leads receive timely information related to FP10 usage, actions required and audit;
Overseeing investigations on their site requested by the Pharmacy Department or by the NHS Counter-fraud Unit pertaining to FP10 use.
4.2.9 Site Designated Senior Pharmacy Technician for FP10 Prescriptions
Overseeing the receipt and supply of FP10 prescriptions from the site pharmacy department;
Routine monitoring of FP10 management by pharmacy against the departmental procedures and this policy;
Delivering training on receipt and supply of FP10 prescriptions to pharmacy staff;

Organising the set-up of a new prescribing area to use FP10 prescriptions, including checking of suitable storage within the setting, arranging training for prescribers if required and inclusion on FP10 audit rota;
Dissemination of information pertaining to FP10s to all Trust staff using FP10 prescriptions;
Ensuring audit is undertaken routinely, with action plans received by divisions/directorates in timely way;
Full engagement and the undertaking of any investigation identified from a discrepancy and requested by the Pharmacy Department or by the NHS Counter- fraud Unit pertaining to FP10 use;
Reporting FP10 usage errors and near miss incidents using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.
4.2.10 Pharmacy Informatics Team
Providing training on use of FP10SS Prescriptions (FP10 for ePrescribing use) and support with IT set up in the clinical area; and maintaining records of this training.
4.2.11 Pharmacy Procurement/ Administrative staff
Ensuring each type of FP10 prescription held is maintained at a rolling 8 week minimum stock level;
Ordering supplies of FP10 prescriptions in a timely manner to avoid stock shortage;
Booking stock of FP10 prescriptions onto Wellsky (formerly JAC) once received;
Securely storing in the appropriate designated locked cabinet(s) within the site pharmacy;
Preparing FP10 prescription ‘packs' for clinical areas in line with departmental SOP;
Only accessing FP10 prescriptions where authorised to do so and once having received departmental training on their use;
4.2.12 Pharmacy Goods Receiving Staff
Upon delivery, verifying stock received and quantity exactly matches the order raised;
Checking serial numbers on delivered FP10 prescription packs exactly match supplier paperwork;
Informing Pharmacy Procurement/Administrative Staff upon delivery and assisting in securely storing in the appropriate designated locked cabinet within the site pharmacy;
Only accessing FP10 prescriptions where authorised to do so and once having received departmental training on their use.
4.2.13 Pharmacy Dispensing Staff
Issuing FP10 prescriptions according to policy and local departmental procedures;
Only accessing FP10 prescriptions where authorised to do so and once having received departmental training on their use;
Maintaining security of FP10 prescriptions at all times by securely storing in the appropriate designated locked cabinet within the site pharmacy.
4.2.14 Prescribers (including non-medical prescribers)
Only issuing FP10 prescriptions when authorised to do so by the pharmacy department;
Requesting permission to use FP10 prescriptions in writing to site Pharmacy Operations Manager;
Ensuring a legal and accurate prescription is generated and provided to the patient in line with this policy and Trust prescribing standards (see Trust prescribing policy, or equivalent);
Ensure FP10 is completed with ALL demographics relating to the patient;
Ensuring the immediate completion of the FP10 issue register upon issuing a FP10 prescription;
When lone working, complete stock checks for all FP10 prescriptions at the start and end of each clinic or shift which ever come first;

When not in use, ensuring all FP10 prescriptions are securely stored in the designated locked cabinet/drawer within the prescribing area (as agreed with the clinical area nurse/midwife manager and pharmacy);

When in use, ensuring FP10 prescriptions are never left unattended (i.e. in an unlocked place, even if out of sight), in any circumstance – Should the prescriber need to leave the clinic room/area and no registered staff remain in the room, the FP10 prescriptions must be moved to the designated locked cabinet/drawer within the clinical area;
Full engagement and the undertaking of any investigation identified from a discrepancy and requested by the Pharmacy Department or by the NHS Counter- fraud Unit pertaining to FP10 use;
Reporting FP10 usage errors and near miss incidents using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.
4.2.15 Accountable Individual (i.e. Registered Nurse/Midwife in charge of a clinical area, often known as Ward Manager/Senior Sister)
Only issuing FP10 prescriptions for use to prescribers in a prescribing area when authorised to do so by the pharmacy department;
Requesting permission to use FP10 prescriptions in writing to site Pharmacy Operational Lead where permission has not already been granted;
Ensuring the area where the prescribing activity will take place has appropriate stock of FP10 prescriptions for the service it provides, collaborating actively with the pharmacy department staff;

Ensuring all staff involved, or that could be involved, with FP10 prescriptions have received the provided training and completed relevant competencies before becoming involved in any part of their use. Records of all training will be retained by them so available on request.
When not in use, ensuring all FP10 prescriptions are securely stored in the designated locked cabinet/drawer within the prescribing area (as agreed with pharmacy);

When in use, ensuring FP10 prescriptions are never left unattended (i.e. in an unlocked place, even if out of sight), in any circumstance – Should the prescriber need to leave the prescribing area and no registered staff remain in the room, the FP10 prescriptions must be moved to the designated locked cabinet/drawer within the clinical area;

Ensuring that record keeping of FP10 prescriptions are accurate, complete and maintained, including completion of stock checks for all FP10 prescriptions at the start and end of each clinic or shift, whichever comes first;
Full engagement and the undertaking of any investigation identified from a discrepancy and any requested by the Pharmacy Department or by the NHS Counter-fraud Unit pertaining to FP10 use;
Reporting FP10 usage errors and near miss incidents using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.
4.2.16 Authorised Person
i.e. registered nurse/midwife or prescriber in charge;
OR another registrant authorised by the registered nurse/midwife in charge as a delegate;
OR approved competency-assessed clinical support staff (i.e. Band 3 and above non-registrants).
Ensuring they only become involved with FP10 management after they have received the provided training and completed competencies;
When not in use, ensuring all FP10 prescriptions are securely stored in the designated locked cabinet/drawer within the prescribing area (as agreed with pharmacy);

When in use, ensuring FP10 prescriptions are never left unattended (i.e. in an unlocked place, even if out of sight), in any circumstance – Should the prescriber need to leave the prescribing area and no registered staff remain in the room, the FP10 prescriptions must be moved to the designated locked cabinet/drawer within the clinical area;

Ordering replacement FP10 prescriptions for departments, clinics and other prescribing areas, ensuring that the current stock holding of FP10 prescriptions is not exceeding the expected number required for one clinic / session only;

Performing and recording stock checks on all FP10 prescriptions at the start and end of each shift/clinic (whichever comes first); and escalating any discrepancy immediately in accordance with this policy;
Ensuring the immediate completion of the FP10 issue register upon the issue of an FP10 prescription;
Full engagement and the undertaking of any investigation identified from a discrepancy and any requested by the Pharmacy Department or by the NHS Counter-fraud Unit pertaining to FP10 use;
Reporting FP10 usage errors and near miss incidents using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.
4.2.17 Competency-assessed clinical support staff (Band  and above non- registrants)

This may be a staff member with other Trust roles (e.g. healthcare assistant etc.) who has undertaken the Trust approved competency framework for FP10 storage & monitoring in clinical areas. Responsible for:
Only undertaking FP10 storage and monitoring tasks where these are agreed with the senior individual in charge of a department (e.g. ward manager);
Undertaking only specifically defined tasks permitted by their competency;
Only accessing FP10s to undertake duties associated with FP10 storage and monitoring;
Maintaining knowledge by adhering to current policy and guidance issued from the pharmacy team;
Reporting FP10 usage errors and near miss incidents using incident reporting system and escalating relevant issues as outlined within this policy.
Types of FP10 prescription
There are 2 types of FP10, both of which are considered to be controlled stationery and must be stored and recorded in accordance with this policy.
FP10NC (Appendix 1)
5.2.1 Pre-printed with a financial code for individual clinic/departments, and therefore speciality specific;
5.2.2 Can only be handwritten.
FP10SS (Appendix 2)
5.3.1 For use with Wellsky (formerly JAC) electronic prescribing system only;
5.3.2 Must NEVER be handwritten. Handwritten FP10SS will NOT be dispensed by a community pharmacy; because they will consider it illegal.
Where FP10 prescriptions can be used
FP10 prescriptions can only be used if authorised, in writing, by the site pharmacy department.
Once authorised, an FP10 can be used by any registered prescriber who understands the legal requirements of using the form.
Once authorised, FP10SS forms can only be used on sites where clinics/departments are using JAC/Wellsky ePrescribing.
Once authorised, FP10NC can only be used by clinics/departments which do not use Wellsky (formerly JAC) ePrescribing.
Where FP10 prescriptions are prohibited
FP10 prescriptions must never be used if authorisation has not been granted, in writing, by the site pharmacy Operational Lead, in any circumstance.
FP10 prescriptions should never be used for the following reasons, regardless of whether a clinic or department has authorisation to use them:
To self-prescribe;
To prescribe for family or friends;
To prescribe for other members of Trust staff;
To prescribe non-formulary medicines. Any prescriber who wishes to prescribe a non-formulary medicine must, in the first instance, always contact the site Clinical Lead Pharmacist for advice.
Authorising usage of FP10 prescriptions in clinical areas
The site pharmacy department has the authority to instruct prescribing areas to use FP10 prescriptions, where determined appropriate. This is corporately agreed for each site.

Prescribing areas themselves may elect to request the use of FP10 prescriptions from the site pharmacy department. All requests must be made in writing to the site Pharmacy Operations Manager well in advance of the proposed implementation date.
Only the Accountable Individual for that prescribing area (see duties above) may make a request to pharmacy.
Accountable Individuals for the prescribing area should send an email to the site Pharmacy Operations Manager containing the following information as a minimum.
Name of prescribing area and speciality;
Rationale for need compared to existing prescription provision;
Brief overview of how clinic operates from prescription writing perspective;
Actual physical location/s of storage of the FP10 prescriptions proposed when not in use;
Actual physical location/s of storage of the FP10 prescriptions proposed when in use;
Volume of usage expected per week and therefore per month;

The site Pharmacy Operations Manager will review requests for FP10 use in a prescribing area, and liaise with the site pharmacy Head of Department in a timely way; and make a decision to approve or decline. This decision will always be made in writing to the Accountable Individual.
Setting up a prescribing area with FP10 prescriptions
The approval of FP10 usage will be accompanied by details specifying the requirements within the prescribing area that MUST be in place before FP10 prescriptions will be supplied. This will include:
Storage facilities – these will need to be confirmed, and seen, by a designated member of pharmacy staff;
Training needs of staff – for both prescribers (medical and non-medical) and nurses/midwives or any other identified staff;
Specific Information Technology requirements (e.g. printers) for implementing FP10SS prescriptions.
Pharmacy will initiate the collation of all required documents, the FP10 issue register and ordering of prescriptions (if required) prior to the expected initiation date.
Training sessions can be organised with pharmacy for the prescribing element (including using ePrescribing for FP10SS) if required.

Training sessions will be delivered by pharmacy with regards to governance arrangements managed by nursing/midwifery. This will include the expected standards of practice that will be audited (see appendix 7).

A site designated pharmacy technician for FP10 prescriptions will work with the Accountable Individual to ensure all requirements (as stated in 9.1) are completed and in place. Only once these are met is the prescribing area ready to receive and start using FP10 prescriptions.
Pharmacy management of FP10 prescriptions
FP10 prescriptions are controlled stationery and must be processed according to site specific pharmacy departmental procedures in terms of handling and secure storage.
The Department of Health and Social Care recommends that no more than three months' stock of prescriptions is to be held by the Trust pharmacy department, on behalf of the prescribing areas.

Upon receipt of FP10 prescriptions from the manufacturer, FP10 prescriptions must be stored securely in the designated lockable and locked ‘FP10 bond' cupboard/cabinet within the site pharmacy department and await ‘packing down' for use in prescribing areas.

Upon completion of the ‘packing down' process (as set out in the pharmacy departmental SOP), all FP10 prescriptions must be stored securely in the designated lockable and locked ‘FP10 supply' cupboard/cabinet within the site pharmacy department.
FP10NC

10.5.1 FP10NC prescription pads are pre-printed with a Trust speciality costing code. Each main clinical speciality has a unique costing code and they must only be supplied to the designated specialty;
10.5.2 Replenishment orders for stock holding of FP10NC pads within pharmacy must be raised for each specific speciality code as per the site specific SOP;
10.5.3 On receipt by pharmacy, the order must be counted and serial numbers checked against the delivery paperwork;

10.5.4 Each prescription pad must have the next sequential log number for the defined cost code allocated. This must be recorded on the speciality-specific pharmacy FP10NC log. The serial numbers from the first and last FP10 within the pad must be recorded against this log number.
FP10SS

10.6.1 FP10SS forms are individual prescription sheets for use with Wellsky (formerly JAC) electronic prescribing only (these will only be used on sites operating electronic prescribing in outpatient settings);

10.6.2 The prescription sheets do not have speciality costing codes pre-printed and as such are not speciality specific. (The speciality costing code is defined by the prescriber that is logged into Wellsky (formerly JAC) and is automatically printed onto the prescription when the prescription is printed);
10.6.3 Orders for stock holding of FP10SS prescriptions must be raised as per the pharmacy site SOP;
10.6.4 On receipt by pharmacy the prescriptions must be counted and serial numbers checked against the delivery paperwork;

10.6.5 FP10SS prescription sheets are ordered in multiples of 1000, and are then packed down into batches of the required number set out in the site pharmacy departmental SOP. Batches are packed into individual sealable bags and never left loose. These batches must be recorded on the FP10SS log in pharmacy and allocated the next sequential log number. The serial numbers from the first and last FP10 within the batch must be recorded against this log number.
FP10 packs for clinical areas

10.7.1 FP10NC and FP10SS are processed by pharmacy into ‘FP10 packs'. Prescribing areas will always receive FP10 supplies as part of an ‘FP10 pack'. Different pack sizes may exist according to site and prescribing area need.
10.7.2 Every pack is assembled as per the site pharmacy departmental procedure as follows:
Packed into a tamper-evident sealed bag;
Labelled clearly with standardised instructions to the clinical area (including secure storage instruction);
FP10 prescriptions packed together in a numerical order;
FP10 issue register;
FP10 re order form.
Prescribing Area: Ordering & Receipt of FP10 prescriptions from
pharmacy
Prescription forms must never be ‘loaned' or ‘swapped' from one prescribing area to another.
Prescribing areas should hold a maximum of 14 days working stock of prescriptions.
For supply of FP10NC or FP10SS please follow appendix 3 – Ordering and supply of FP10 prescriptions from pharmacy.

Ordering of FP10NC or FP10SS can only be made against a designated order form (appendix 4 or 5). For first time ordering this will not be accepted by the pharmacy department until sections 8 & 9 of this policy are met.
Only an Authorised Person (registered nurse/midwife/prescriber authorised by the Accountable Individual of the prescribing area) may order FP10 prescriptions.

The ordering registered nurse/midwife/prescriber, by making the order, is taking responsibility for declaring that the current stock holding of FP10 prescriptions does not exceed the expected number required for 14 days of clinics/sessions; and replenishment is therefore required.
Onsite prescribing areas
11.7.1 Refer to appendix
11.7.2 A telephone call to the site pharmacy must be made in advance of the order and agreement on a time to attend the site pharmacy dispensary to receive the order.

11.7.3 Only a registered nurse/midwife/prescriber may collect the FP10 supply and must have a valid Trust photo ID badge to present at the point of collection. Pharmacy staff have authority to refuse orders and collections of FP10 supplies without this.
11.7.4 Upon arrival back to the clinic/department, the registered nurse/midwife/prescriber who collected the FP10 supply must complete the following;
The front of the FP10 issue register;
Enter each FP10 serial number into the issue register in the serial number column, ready for use;
Securely store the FP10 supply in a locked cabinet/drawer in the designated location (see section 12).
Offsite prescribing areas
11.8.1 Refer to appendix
11.8.2 A telephone call to the site pharmacy must be made in advance of the order and an agreement on the date to send the order of FP10 prescriptions out by hospital courier.

11.8.3 Only hospital couriers or staff authorised by the Accountable Individual may be tasked with the transport of stock FP10 prescriptions to off-site prescribing areas. The use of a taxi is NOT allowed.

11.8.4 Once the FP10 supply reaches the prescribing site, they must be handed directly to the nurse/midwife/prescriber that placed the order. The consignment slip must be signed, dated and sent back to the site pharmacy department as proof of receipt.
11.8.5 The registered nurse/midwife/prescriber who signed for the supply of FP10 prescriptions must complete the following;
The front of the FP10 issue register;
Enter each FP10 serial number into the issue register in the serial number column, ready for use;
Securely store the FP10 supply in a locked cabinet/drawer in the designated location (see section 12).
Prescribing Area: Secure storage of FP10 prescriptions
When not in use, FP10 prescriptions must be securely locked in a cupboard or safe which is located in an area that is inaccessible to the public out of hours.

The securely locked cupboard/safe must have controlled access. Only staff authorised & trained to handle FP10 prescriptions must be in possession of the keys; or have access the key safe (if one exists).
Where a key-code is used the access code must be changed, as a minimum, every 6 months.
FP10 prescriptions must never be kept in any area where there is not a facility to lock them away without any unauthorised access.
The Accountable Individual (registered nurse/midwife/prescriber in charge) and prescriber(s) are accountable for the security of FP10 prescriptions once issued to them by pharmacy.

When in use, prescribers must never leave FP10 prescriptions unattended if it becomes necessary for them to leave the room, even if only momentarily. The expectation is that if no registered Health Care Professional is present within the prescribing room, the FP10 prescription forms MUST be locked away. Lockable facilities must be available in the prescribing room to enable this to be done, and control over access to the keys must be as stated above.
Prescribers, registered nurses/midwives or any other staff must never carry FP10 prescriptions on their person, except for the purpose of transporting from pharmacy to their destination.
Forms must never be left unattended in cars, briefcases etc.
Record keeping: Issuing FP10 prescriptions and stock checking
Record keeping of FP10 prescriptions should be treated as comparable to the issue/supply of controlled drugs.
Record keeping must be accurate, unambiguous and timely.
FP10 prescriptions must only be issued against the FP10 issue register for that pack of FP10s.

A fully completed issue log ensures a full audit trail will be available for each singular FP10. This will allow the ‘history' of a prescription to be traced from receipt of the blank form to when it is prescribed.
FP10 prescriptions must be issued in sequential order by, or to, the prescriber.
A complete entry for each FP10 issued MUST be documented in the FP10 issue register which is used to record the following information:
Serial number of the prescription issued;
Patient name to whom the prescription has been issued;
Hospital unit number of the patient to whom the prescription has been issued;
Date and time of issue to the patient;
Prescribers printed name in full;
Prescriber signature.

A stock check for each FP10 pack / issue register held in the prescribing area must be performed at least once a day, on every day that the prescribing area is open (regardless of whether FP10s have been used or not). This is the responsibility of the nurse/midwife in charge or prescriber (where working alone) to ensure this happens. It may be delegated to any authorised person (as described in section 4 of this policy). The stock check must include:
Checking all transaction lines in the register are complete, without gaps;
Checking the total number of FP10 prescriptions physically present exactly matches the unissued number remaining in the FP10 issue register;
Any discrepancies must be immediately actioned and pharmacy informed (see section  below).
The stock check must be documented using the ‘stock check log' section within the FP10 issue register.
All completed FP10 issue registers must be retained by the prescribing area for 2 years from date of last entry.
Prescribing on FP10 Prescriptions
In order for a community pharmacy to dispense an  FP10, the prescriber must ensure that the prescription is;
Legal;
Completed correctly, accurately and signed, in accordance with the Trust Prescribing policy, or equivalent. For FP10NC's, refer to Appendix 1 for completion guidance;
The prescribing must be in accordance with the Trust's formulary and quantities limited to one original pack or maximum of 30 days, unless otherwise agreed by the pharmacy department.
The prescriber must sign the FP10 and print their name alongside their signature in indelible ink.

FP10SS prescriptions must only be used by clinics using Wellsky (formerly JAC) electronic prescribing. Handwritten FP10SS will NOT be dispensed by a community pharmacy; because they will consider it illegal.

Only items approved on the Trust Medicines Formulary can be prescribed on an FP10 prescription. This is the same expected standard as prescribing for inpatients, discharge or outpatients using a hospital prescription.

Prescribing on FP10 forms is tracked nationally and the Trust runs regular reports from the NHS Business Authority website of what has been prescribed on an FP10. Unusual or inappropriate prescribing will be notified to the prescriber and clinical directorate as appropriate. Further actions and recommendations will be issued by the pharmacy directorate if needed.
If a prescription is written in error, or is spoiled, then this should be managed as per appendix
Managing FP10 Discrepancies

If a discrepancy in the quantity of FP10 prescriptions within the prescribing area is discovered, (e.g. missing /lost, or suspected theft of an FP10) action must be taken as soon as possible, as any delays can make it impossible to identify what has happened. The identifying person must inform the registered nurse/midwife or prescriber in charge immediately.
Appendix 7 must be followed in all instances.
There are two possible scenarios: either the FP10 issue register amount is greater than the physical amount present or the FP10 issue register amount is less than the physical amount present.

The registered nurse/midwife or prescriber in charge must investigate any discrepancy immediately. If they are unavailable, their deputy or a matron must undertake this task. Every possible step must be explored, which can take time but it is necessary to complete the entire investigation.
For discrepancies within pharmacy only, the site designated Senior Pharmacy Technician for FP10 prescriptions must undertake this task.
Discrepancies are either ‘simple record-keeping' errors or are otherwise ‘complex'. These require different responses.
Simple record-keeping errors
15.7.1 Simple record-keeping errors are typically where there is a straightforward minor documentation issue only, such as a type-error;

15.7.2 The cause of the discrepancy must have been immediately identified (i.e. within a few minutes) and the cause of the discrepancy is without any doubt (i.e.100% sure). Pharmacy staff should be consulted for advice, if needed;

15.7.3 Simple record-keeping entries may be corrected in the FP10 issue register. This correction can be made by a registered member of staff. The correcting registrant must be witnessed. It is good practice for the two persons involved in entering the correction, not to be the same as the persons involved in the error. Where there is not a second registrant to witness the correction, a member of pharmacy staff can be contacted or the Clinical Site Manager if pharmacy is closed;
15.7.4 Ensure the resolution of the discrepancy is updated on the stock check page in the FP10 issue register, if found at a routine stock check.
Complex discrepancies
15.8.1 Complex means that the cause of the discrepancy cannot be found immediately and/or there is doubt as to the cause of the discrepancy (including not being satisfied with explanations given);
15.8.2 If the discrepancy remains unresolved, the registered nurse/midwife or prescriber in charge must also immediately inform verbally:
the Matron (duty Sister in charge if out of hours);
the ward/dept. named Pharmacist (if out of hours this must be done the next day). They in turn will liaise with the appropriate senior pharmacy staff;
emails should be avoided in case they are not picked up promptly.
For complex discrepancies an incident report form must be submitted as soon as possible, regardless of whether the discrepancy was subsequently resolved or not.
Complex discrepancy investigations must be recorded on the FP10 discrepancy investigation form available on the intranet or from pharmacy.
The discrepancy form must have all relevant sections completed. The content of the investigation includes:
Detailed specifics about the discrepancy (e.g. specific FP10 number/s which are missing, timings of when identified and when stock checks last undertaken);
Staff on duty for the time period concerned, identifying those who had FP10 cupboard/cabinet keys in their possession prior to the identified discrepancy;
Written statements from all appropriate staff members;

Key findings that might have a bearing on the discrepancy (examples may include FP10 policy non-compliances, FP10 issue register entries that are illegible, incomplete, ambiguously corrected or crossed out);
Conclusions made.
Some discrepancies will warrant greater concern than others such as the quantity of the discrepancy.
The FP10 discrepancy investigation form must be completed electronically by the registered nurse/midwife or prescriber in charge and emailed to the address on the form.

The site pharmacy Operational Manager and site pharmacy Head of Department must be informed immediately where there is any suspicion of misuse or diversion (i.e. theft / fraud). They will co-ordinate any further investigation in collaboration with the Trust Local Security Management Specialist (LSMS).

The site pharmacy Head of Department and/or LSMS will authorise and liaise, as appropriate, with Essex Police. They will inform the relevant commissioning body Accountable Officer to ensure wider intelligence networks, including those who link with community pharmacies, are aware. The Chief Pharmacist will be notified.
For complex discrepancies, the corrective entry in the FP10 register may only be witnessed by registered pharmacy staff acting on authority from the site pharmacy Operational Manager.
The incident form must be updated with the outcome of the investigation.

Every FP10 discrepancy investigation form is reviewed by the designated site FP10 senior pharmacy technician. They support the site pharmacy Operational Manager and site pharmacy Head of Department in determining any further actions, if appropriate.
If the discrepancy was found at a routine stock check, the stock check log page should be updated to reflect the outcome of the discrepancy investigation.
Pharmacy maintains records of all staff involved and themes/trends with regards to discrepancies for all prescribing areas and pharmacy dispensaries, for all sites.

Any identified cause for concern, such as repeat involvement of the same staff member and/or same prescribing area, will be escalated to the relevant prescribing area managers and a formal action plan will be issued by the site pharmacy Head of Department to be completed and evidenced.

If the FP10 discrepancy cannot be resolved or identified, the Chief Pharmacist, or site pharmacy Head of Department will escalate to NHSBA if deemed appropriate, in addition to Essex Police (see above).
Outcomes and learning from investigations are exception reported at MSE Medicines Assurance Group (MAG) and shared with the NHSBA.
Correcting an error in the FP10 issue register
Error corrections must be documented in the FP10 issue register using the same principles as with controlled drug register documentation.
Errors must never be cancelled (e.g. crossed through), obliterated (e.g. scribbled over) or altered (e.g. overwritten).
Liquid paper correction fluid (e.g. Tippex™), or sticky labels must never be used.
An error should be corrected as follows:
16.4.1 On the issue log page put brackets ( ) around the error and mark entry with an asterisk ‘';

16.4.2 At bottom of the issue log page, enter a footnote: begin with an  and then write an entry to explain the error (‘Entered in error') then add your signature and ask the witness to add their signature, date and time;
16.4.3 Only enter reasons as footnotes and not anywhere else on the page;

16.4.4 Add an explanation for the corrective entry on the stock check log page of the FP10 issue register. (Date, time, ‘Stock balance corrected', names of responsible person and witness. New stock balance).
Training Requirements
Pharmacy staff, appropriate to their role, are trained in the management of FP10 prescriptions by the site designated senior technician for FP10 management.
Accountable individuals will receive technical training on the governance arrangement for FP10 prescriptions from designated pharmacy technicians.
Authorised individuals are trained by accountable individuals on this policy and the competencies required.
Prescribers will be trained on how to generate a legal prescription using ePrescribing.

Prescribers are expected, within the course of their profession, to always furnish legal prescriptions to patients. As such prescribing accuracy is not specifically taught and prescribers must refer to the Trust prescribing policy, appendix 1 of this document or a clinical pharmacist if still unsure; before supplying the FP10 prescription.

Appendix 8: Audit Standards

table_items.text: Is a registered nurse/midwife or prescriber (or authorised competency-assessed staff member) in possession of the keys for FP10 storage when they are being used. (Yes or No).

When in use, does the prescribing area where FP10s are issued have a lockable drawer/cupboard for securing FP10s, if room is temporarily unattended. (Ask nurse/midwife/prescriber to show you rooms used, and the facility for locking away in drawer). N/A - Where single FP10s are issued one at a time by a nurse/midwife to a prescriber. This must be asked and documented in ‘comments' on audit form.

FP10s that are not in current use are locked away in either a locked cupboard/drawer or safe, where only registered nurses/midwives/prescribers have access (or authorised competency-assessed staff member) (Ask the nurse present what happens. Do not lead the question with examples of the right answer. No receptionists/ward clerks or any other non-registrants (except authorised competency-assessed staff) must have access to the key cabinet if this facility is used).

A reasonable amount of FP10s are held in stock. There should be no more than 28 days worth of FP10 forms within the prescribing area. The only exception to this is where a single supply of 50 prescriptions exceeds this usage (Look in the FP10 register and count up how many FP10 prescriptions have been issued within the last 28 days)

The only FP10 packs held by the prescribing area are for that specific department (Check against pharmacy issue log which pack numbers have been issued to designated clinic/prescriber. This check must be made on the day of the audit pre visit. Verify these are the only ones present. Use the front of the registers to verify corresponding pack numbers). (Note any packs/FP10s found which do not correspond must be immediately followed up with the designated pharmacy senior technician for FP10s – or deputy).

There is a documented and fully complete record of the daily stock check of FP10s. (Every day the prescribing area is in use, a documented stock check must take place and be recorded on the stock check log within the issue register.
The stock balance present in each register within the prescribing area matches those FP10 forms physically present. (Yes or No).

Within every FP10 issue register in the prescribing area, every transaction is fully completed. (Every transaction must have full serial number used, patient hospital number, date and time of issue, prescribers name and signature).
All register entries and/or corrections are legible and clear, written indelibly (i.e. in ink). (There are no illegible entries/tip-ex/stickers or written in pencil).

Are there any discrepancies identified or documented in registers? If YES – Have these discrepancies been actioned and escalated to pharmacy as per policy. (There should be clear a documented entry with explanation for each discrepancy, with an incident report number and entry from pharmacy where appropriate).
